choices.text: Apprehensive anxiety about additional panic attacks
Phobic avoidance i.e., avoiding the place/situation in which panic attack occurs

questions.text: Which of the following criteria should be present along with Panic attacks to make a diagnosis of Panic disorder according to DSM-V?
questions.solution:
According to DSM-V diagnostic criteria for panic disorder, at least one of the panic attacks should be followed by 1 month(or more) of one or both of the following:

  1. Persistent concern or worry about additional panic attacks or their consequences (e.g., losing control, having a heart attack, "going crazy")[APPREHENSIVE ANXIETY](Option A)
  2. A significant maladaptive change in behaviour related to the attacks (e.g., behaviours designed to avoid having panic attacks, such as avoidance of exercise or unfamiliar situations)[PHOBIC AVOIDANCE](Option B)

Thus, it requires panic attacks as well as apprehensive anxiety about panic attacks and phobic avoidance to fulfil criteria for panic disorder.

Fear of dying or impending doom or losing control are symptoms of panic attack.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 9.2, Panic Disorder, Page 394.

questions.text: Which of the following is an area of the brain which appears to be most closely related to anxiety based on functional imaging studies?
questions.solution:
• Functional imaging studies have consistently showed the amygdala playing a central role in the area of anxiety
  • The amygdala is an almond-shaped mass of grey matter located as part of the limbic system

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 9, Anxiety disorders, Page no. 391.

questions.text: All of the following are terms used in context of factitious disorder except:
questions.solution:
• Richard Asher coined the term "Munchausen syndrome" to refer to a syndrome in which patients embellish their personal history, chronically fabricate symptoms to gain hospital admission, and move from hospital to hospital
  • The syndrome was named after Baron Hieronymus Friedrich Freiherr von Munchausen, a German cavalry officer
  • Other symptoms, which also appear in factitious disorder, include pseudologia fantastica and impostership
  • In pseudologiafantastica(Option B), limited factual material is mixed with extensive and colourful fantasies. Patients often give false and conflicting accountsabout other areas of their lives (e.g., they may claim the death of a parent, to play on the sympathy of others)
  • Imposture is commonly related to lying in these cases. Many patients assume the identity of a prestigious person. Men, for example, report being war heroes and attribute their surgical scars to wounds received during battle or in other dramatic and dangerous exploits
  • Factitious disorder has also been called hospital addiction, polysurgical addiction-producing the so-called washboard abdomen, professional patient syndrome, hospital hobos, among other names
  • Ganser syndrome - however, is a poorly understood condition characterized by the giving of approximate answers (paralogia) together with a clouding of consciousness and is frequently accompanied by hallucinations and other dissociative, somatoform, or conversion symptoms. However, there is no factitious element in Ganser syndrome

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 13.6, Factitious Disorder, Page 489

questions.text: A 38-year-old divorced female professor, belonging to high socio-economic class, was reprimanded many times for charges of shop-lifting, which she had started at the age of 22. She would steal only on impulse, not from premediation, and experienced tension prior to, and satisfaction after shoplifting. The stolen items included crayons, spoons, candles, coloured papers, earrings, etc. which she hoarded in her cupboard. The correct diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
• The essential feature of kleptomania is a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects not needed for personal use or for monetary value.
  • Persons with kleptomania usually have the money to pay for the objects they impulsively steal.
  • As with other impulse-control disorders, kleptomania is characterized by mounting tension before the act, followed by gratification and lessening of tension with or without guilt, remorse, or depression after the act.
  • Pyromania is recurrent, deliberate and purposeful setting of fires. (Option A)
  • Intermittent explosive disorder is characterised by episodes of temper out-bursts intermittently (Option C)
  • Conduct disorder is seen in childhood and characterised by violation of societal norms or rules (Option D)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 19, Disruptive, Impulse control, and Conduct disorders, Page number 611.

questions.text: A female patient of bipolar disorder is on lithium for last 1 year. Which of the following side effects is least likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Tardive dyskinesia is an EPS, side effect of antipsychotic drug.

Remaining all others are the S/Es of Lithium

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiaitry, 11th Edition, Chapter 29, Page No. 927, 985-987

choices.text: The major source of Vitamin D synthesis is the skin.
The major function of Vitamin D is calcium homeostasis.
Its actions are mediated by extranuclear receptors.
Intake higher than that required, reduces the risk of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and cancers.

questions.text: Following is false regarding Vitamin D?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin D is not strictly a vitamin since it can be synthesised in the skin, and in most conditions, this is the major source of the vitamin. Only when sunlight exposure is inadequate, a dietary source is required.
  • Its main function is in the regulation of calcium absorption and homeostasis most of its actions are mediated by way of nuclear receptors that regulate gene expression. It also has a role in regulating cell proliferation and differentiation.
  • There is evidence that intakes considerably higher than are required to maintain calcium homeostasis reduce the risk of insulin resistance, obesity, and the metabolic syndrome, as well as various cancers.
  • Deficiency, leading to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, is a problem in northern latitudes, where sunlight exposure is inadequate

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-1297.

choices.text: Zellweger syndrome is also called cerebrohepatorenal syndrome
Refsum's disease is a common disorder caused by phytanic acid accumulation
Zellweger syndrome is characterised by absence of peroxisomes in the brain only

questions.text: True regarding peroxisomal disorders?
questions.solution:
Lorenzo oil is used for the treatment of Adrenoleukodystrophy. Zellweger Syndrome, also called cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, occurs in individuals with a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues. They accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids (VLCFA) in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions.

The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

Refsum disease is a rare neurologic disorder caused by a metabolic defect (absence of enzyme phytanoyl CoA dioxygenase) that results in the accumulation of phytanic acid. Phytanic Acid is found in dairy products and ruminant fat and meat.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, page 532

choices.text: A/K/A familial dysbetalipoproteinemia/Familial broad beta disease
Chylomicron remnant and VLDL are elevated

questions.text: Which of the following is false about type 3 hyperlipoproteinemia?
questions.solution:
Type 3 hyperlipoproteinemia is also called Familial dysbetalipoproteinemia or broad beta disease or remnant removal disease. It is characterized by tuberoeruptive xanthomas on the knees, buttocks, and elbows. Palmar xanthomas, a condition called xanthoma striata palmaris, is specific to hyperlipoproteinemia type III and has not been reported in any other disorder.

The risk for developing coronary heart disease is 5-10 times higher for an individual with hyperlipoproteinemia type III compared to the general population. Individuals with hyperlipoproteinemia type III may eventually develop inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis). Chronic pancreatitis may result in back pain, diarrhoea, yellow-coloured skin (jaundice), and potentially the development of diabetes. Pancreatitis can also lead to the development of pancreatic cancer. It is due to the mutation of the ApoE gene.

Apo-E acts as a mediator for remnant uptake and its mutation causes increase in plasma levels of chylomicron remnant and VLDL. There is an increase in plasma levels of cholesterol and TG's.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 8th South Asian Edition, Page Number-698.

questions.text: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of which of the following enzymes after addition of FAD in vitro?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiamine diphosphate is also the coenzyme for transketolase, in the pentose phosphate pathway. The activation of transketolase in erythrocyte lysate by thiamine diphosphate added in vitro has become the accepted index of thiamine nutritional status.

Option B: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by the measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option C: Vitamin B6 status is assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminases. The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro.

Option D: Transaldolase is an enzyme in the HMP shunt. It is not used to assess riboflavin status.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page Number-534.

questions.text: Methyl malonic aciduria occurs due to deficiency of which of the following vitamin?
questions.solution:
• Methylmalonyl-CoA is formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine and by the carboxylation of propionyl-CoA arising in the catabolism of isoleucine, cholesterol, and rare fatty acids with an odd number of carbon atoms, or directly from propionate, a major product of microbial fermentation ruminants.
  • It undergoes a vitamin B12 dependent rearrangement to succinyl-CoA, catalyzed by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase. This enzyme requires vitamin B12 as coenzyme.
  • The activity of this enzyme is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid (Methylmalonic aciduria), which provides a means of assessing vitamin B12 nutritional status.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 44, Pg 536

questions.text: Osazone is formed by all of the following compound except
questions.solution:
• All reducing sugars will form osazones with excess of phenyl hydrazine when kept at boiling temperature.
    • Osazones are insoluble.
    • Each sugar will have characteristic crystal form of osazones, differences in glucose, fructose and mannose are dependent on the first and second carbon atoms, and when the osazone is formed these differences are masked. Hence these 3 sugars will produce the same needle shaped crystals arranged like sheaves of corn or a broom.
  • SHAPES OF OSAZONES
    • Needle-shaped/Broomstick/Sheaves of Corn-Glucose, Fructose, Mannose
    • Pincushion with pins/Hedgehog/Flower of Touch-me-not-Lactose
    • Sunflower Petal-shaped-Maltose
    • Note: Sucrose does not form osazones

Reference: DM Vasudevan, S Sreekumari, 8th edition, page no. 92

questions.text: A person has been doing regular exercise in gym. He is taking high carbohydrate diet but while doing the exercise he is not able to perform his best. He feels his capacity of doing exercise is reduced. Deficiency of which glycolytic enzyme in skeletal muscles is responsible for fatigue in this patient.
questions.solution:
• The exercise capacity of patients with muscle phosphofructokinase deficiency (GSD-VII) is low, particularly if they are on high-carbohydrate diets.
  • By providing lipid as an alternative fuel, for example, during starvation, when blood free fatty acid and ketone bodies are increased, work capacity is improved.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, Page no.174

choices.text: Low blood glucose less than 40 mg%

questions.text: Acetone is increase in serum of a patient of von gierke's disease, so what is the reasons for ketosis in this disease are all except:
questions.solution:
Glucose-6 phosphatase deficiency leads to hypoglycaemia. This enzyme is required for both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, the two pathways by which blood glucose levels are maintained.

Pyruvate and lactate are converted to oxaloacetate for gluconeogenesis.

Due to hypoglycaemia, there is high mobilisation of fatty acid from adipose tissue. Hypoglycaemia lowers blood insulin levels, which is an inhibitor of hormone sensitive lipase (HSL); low insulin levels result in loss of this inhibition, and TG stores in adipocytes are broken down by the action of HSL.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, Page no.179

questions.text: Which of the following things are required for oxidative decarboxylation function of Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex:
questions.solution:
• The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a aggregate of three enzymes, pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1, also called a decarboxylase), dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2) and dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase(E3)
  • The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex contains five coenzymes that act as carriers or oxidants for the intermediates of the reactions. E1 requires thiamine pyrophosphate, E2 requires lipoic acid and coenzyme A, and E3 requires FAD and NAD+.

References: Lippincott SAE, Page no. 208; Harper's, 32nd edition, chapter - 17

questions.text: A breast feed infant come with frequent vomiting and lose of weight. After many days he have develop jaundice, hepatomegaly, bilateral cataract. What is the possible diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:

choices.text: Fatty acids that are required by humans, but are not synthesized in the body hence need to be supplied in the diet
Humans lack the enzymes that can introduce double bond beyond 9th Carbon.
Arachidonic Acid is considered as semi essential fatty Acid as it can be synthesized from Oleic Acid.
Linoleic Acid is the Most Essential Fatty Acid

questions.text: All sentences are true about essential fatty acid except?
questions.solution:
• SOME POLYUNSATURATED FATTY ACIDS CANNOT BE SYNTHESIZED BY MAMMALS & ARE NUTRITIONALLY ESSENTIAL
  • Linoleic and α-linolenic acids are the only fatty acids known to be essential for the complete nutrition of many species of animals, including humans, and are termed the nutritionally essential fatty acids.
  • In most mammals, arachidonic acid can be formed from linoleic acid. Double bonds can be introduced at the δ4, δ5, δ6, and δ9 positions in most animals, but never beyond the δ9 position.
  • In contrast, plants are able to synthesize the nutritionally essential fatty acids by introducing double bonds at the δ12 and δ15 positions.
  • Linoleic Acid is the Most Essential Fatty Acid Arachidonic Acid is considered as Semi essential fatty Acid as it can be synthesized from Linoleic Acid

Functions of essential fatty acid

  • They are integral components of membrane structure, often in the 2 position of phospholipids
  • Eicosanoids are synthesized from Arachidonic Essential fatty acids are needed for the synthesis of Arachidonic Acid
  • Lower the risk of Cardiovascular

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, page 222, 238

questions.text: A short stature male presented with enlarged and weak heart muscle, weakness of skeletal muscle, recurrent infection and diagnosed with Barth syndrome. Which of the following lipid component is decreased in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Phosphatidic acid is a precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, which in turn gives rise to cardiolipin. This phospholipid is found only in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function. Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathological conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism, and Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, page 217

questions.text: Which of the following type of histone covalent modification is associated with DNA repair?
questions.solution:
Option A: Methylation of histones is correlated with activation and repression of gene transcription.

Option B: ADP-ribosylation of histones is associated with DNA repair.

Option C: Sumoylation of histones is associated with transcription repression

Option D: Acetylation of is associated with chromosomal assembly during DNA replication

These four core histones are subject to at least six types of covalent modification or posttranslational modifications (PTMs): acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, ADP-ribosylation, monoubiquitylation, and sumoylation. These histone modifications play important roles in chromatin structure and function, as given in following table:

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 35, Pg 353

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the polymerization of ribonucleotides into a sequence complementary to the template strand of the gene during transcription?
questions.solution:
Option A: DNA Polymerase is responsible for replication of DNA.

Option B: RNA polymerase catalyzes the polymerization of ribonucleotides into an RNA sequence that is complementary to the template strand of the gene.

Option C: reverse transcriptase is RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, a class of enzymes capable of synthesizing a single-stranded and then a dsDNA molecule from a single-stranded RNA template. It exists in retroviruses.

Option D: Peptidyl transferase is an enzyme that helps in formation of peptide bonds during protein synthesis (translation).

DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RNAP) is the enzyme responsible for the polymerization of ribonucleotides into a sequence complementary to the template strand of the gene. The enzyme attaches at a specific site-the promoter-on the DNA template. This is followed by initiation of RNA synthesis at the starting point, and the process continues until a termination sequence is reached.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 36, Pg 376

questions.text: The major process which produces purine nucleotide for synthesis of DNA during cell division is:
questions.solution:
The three processes that contribute to purine nucleotide biosynthesis are, in order of decreasing importance:

  1. Synthesis from amphibolic intermediates (synthesis de novo)
  2. Phosphoribosylation of purines
  3. Phosphorylation of purine nucleosides

Option A: All dietary nucleic acids and nucleotides are nonessential, they will not be incorporated into tissue nucleic acids. Following ingestion of nucleotide or nucleic acid in diet, their degradation results in mononucleotides, which may be absorbed or converted to purine and pyrimidine bases. The purine bases are then oxidized to uric acid, which may be absorbed and excreted in the urine. Pyrimidine bases are degraded into CO2, NH3, beta alanine and beta aminoisobutyrate.

Option B: De novo synthesis is a major pathway which provides nucleotides to tissue to meet their physiological demands. During de novo synthesis in tissue, purine or pyrimidine nucleotides are produced from various amphibolic intermediates.

Option C: During phosphorylation of purines, there is an addition of ribose phosphate to preformed purine or pyrimidine bases.

Option D: During phosphorylation of purine nucleosides, there is an addition of phosphate to the nucleoside.

Both phosphorylation of purines and Phosphorylation of purine nucleosides occurs during the salvage pathway. Such purine or pyrimidine bases or purine nucleosides are derived from damaged DNA of broken down cells (recycled).

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 33, Pg 328

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with pallor, jaundice and abnormal enlargement of liver and spleen. On investigation he has low Hb and hypochromic microcytic anemia. He was diagnosed to have beta thalassemia major. β-thalassemia, a disease in which the β-globin gene of hemoglobin leads to reduced synthesis of the beta chain leading to inadequate HbA formation. Which of the following processes are most likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
A defect in mRNA splicing can cause disease. One of the first examples of the critical importance of accurate splicing was the discovery that one form of β-thalassemia, a disease in which the β-globin gene of hemoglobin is severely under expressed results from a nucleotide change at an exon-intron junction. This mutation precludes removal of the intron, altering the translational reading frame of β-globin mRNA, thereby blocking the β-chain protein production and hence hemoglobin.

So option A is correct, rest are incorrect options.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 36 PN 389

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9)

Option A: RISPR-Cas9 is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique.

Option B & Option C: CRISPR-Cas9 is a RNA-directed site specific endonuclease.

Option D: CAS9 is CRISPR associated protein 9, has an endonuclease enzyme activity which used CRISPR sequences as a guide. Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR-Cas9

It is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique

It was recognized by Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer Doudna (awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2020).

CRISPR: clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats

  • CRISPR found in genomes of prokaryotic organisms (in bacteria and archaea).

It found in approximately 50% of sequenced bacterial genomes and 90% of sequenced archaea.

  • These sequences are originally derived from DNA fragments of bacteriophages that had previously infected the prokaryote.

Later they are used by prokaryotes to detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages during subsequent infections to prokaryotes.

So these sequences play role as an antiviral (antiphase) defense system for prokaryotes and provide an acquired or adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection of a bacterium by specific bacteriophages

  • CRISPR complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

CAS9: CRISPR associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA).
  • Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

The CRISPR system has been also adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including human cells, where it has been shown to be an RNA-directed site-specific nuclease just as it is in bacteria.

  • It has wide varieties of application in medicine, in basic biological research, food and farming industries.

In medicine, it was used experimentally to treat a patient with a genetic disorder (e.g. sickle cell disease), to treat viral infection like HIV etc.

  • Variations on the use of CRISPR allow for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and even modulation of gene transcription in basic biological research.

Thus, CRISPR has added an exciting new, highly efficient, and very specific technology to the toolbox of methods for the manipulation of DNA and genetic analysis of mammalian cells.

  • A variant of the CRISPR-Cas system, C2c2, has been shown to site-specifically cleave RNA. This exciting discovery paves the way for potential specific alteration of mRNA levels in human cells.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 39 PN 435

questions.text: First purine nucleotide synthesized by de novo biosynthesis is:
questions.solution:
During de novo biosynthesis, the first nucleotide synthesized is Inosine monophosphate (IMP). Then IMP →AMP, also IMP →XMP →GMP

Option A: AMP is produced from IMP.

Option B: GMP is produced from XMP, which is produced from IMP

Option C: IMP is the first nucleotide which is produced by de novo biosynthesis of purine.

Option D: XMP is produced from IMP

De novo biosynthesis of purine nucleotides reactions:


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 33 PN 330

choices.text: Energetically costlier than de novo purine biosynthesis
CPS II is a mitochondrial enzyme
PRPP serves as a scaffold for assembly of the pyrimidine ring
Multifunctional proteins catalyze early reaction of pyrimidine biosynthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pyrimidine biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Compared to biosynthesis of pyrimidines, purine nucleoside biosynthesis is energetically more costly

Option B: The catalyst for the initial reaction is cytosolic carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II.

A different enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, used in urea synthesis (urea cycle) is present in mitochondria.

Such compartmentation thus provides an independent pool of carbamoyl phosphate for each process.

Option C: PRPP serves as a scaffold for assembly of the purine ring in purine biosynthesis. Whereas PRPP participates in pyrimidine biosynthesis only subsequent to assembly of the pyrimidine ring.

Option D: Multifunctional proteins catalyze the early reactions of pyrimidine biosynthesis.

Five of the first six enzyme activities of pyrimidine biosynthesis reside on multifunctional polypeptides. The close proximity of multiple active sites on a multifunctional polypeptide facilitates efficient channeling of the intermediates of pyrimidine biosynthesis.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 33 PN 332

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription is 5'-GTACTAG-3'. What is the base sequence of the RNA product?
questions.solution:
The RNA product has a sequence that is complementary to the template strand and identical to the coding strand of DNA. The RNA transcript has the same polarity (5'-3') as the coding strand but contains U rather than T.

Thus, the DNA template 5'-GTACTAG-3'

would produce the RNA product 3'-CAUGAUC-5' or,

written correctly in standard direction, 5'-CUAGUAC-3'.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition CH 36 PN 380

questions.text: Progress through the mammalian cell cycle is continuously monitored via multiple cell-cycle checkpoints. Which of the following cyclin dependent kinases (CDK) regulates transition of cell cycle from G2 to M phase?
questions.solution:
Option A: CDK1 involve in transition from G2 to M

Option B: CDK2 involves the initiation of DNA synthesis in the early S phase.

Option C & Option D: CDK4 & CDK6 are involved in progression past the restriction point in G1/S boundary.

All eukaryotic cells have gene products that govern the transition from one phase of the cell cycle to another. The cyclins are a family of proteins whose concentration increases and decreases at specific times, that is, "cycle" during the cell cycle - thus their name. The cyclins thus activate, at the appropriate time, different cyclin-dependent protein kinases (CDKs) that phosphorylate substrates essential for progression through the cell cycle.

For example, cyclin D levels rise in late G1 phase and allow progression beyond the start (yeast) or restriction point (mammals), the point beyond which cells irrevocably proceed into the S or DNA synthesis phase.

The D cyclins activate CDK4 and CDK6. These two kinases are also synthesized during G1 in cells undergoing active division. The D cyclins and CDK4 and CDK6 are nuclear proteins that assemble as a complex in late G1 phase. The cyclin-CDK complex is now an active serine - threonine protein kinase. One substrate for this kinase is the retinoblastoma (Rb) protein. Rb is a cell-cycle regulator because it binds to and inactivates a transcription factor (E2F) necessary for the transcription of certain genes (histone genes, DNA replication proteins, etc) needed for progression from G1 to S phase. The phosphorylation of Rb by CDK4 or CDK6 results in the release of E2F from Rb-mediated transcription repression - thus, gene transcription activation ensues and cell-cycle progression takes place.

Cyclin E and CDK2 form a complex in late G1. Cyclin E is rapidly degraded, and the released CDK2 then forms a complex with cyclin A. This sequence is necessary for the initiation of DNA synthesis in S phase. A complex between cyclin B and CDK1 is rate-limiting for the G2/M transition in eukaryotic cells.

Many of the cancer-causing viruses (oncoviruses) and cancer-inducing genes (oncogenes) are capable of alleviating or disrupting the restriction that normally controls the entry of mammalian cells from G1 into the S phase. From the foregoing, one might have surmised that excessive production of a cyclin, loss of a specific CDK inhibitor, or production or activation of a cyclin/CDK at an inappropriate time might result in abnormal or unrestrained cell division. Similarly, the oncoproteins (or transforming proteins) produced by several DNA viruses target the Rb transcription repressor for inactivation, inducing cell division inappropriately, while inactivation of Rb, itself a tumor suppressor gene, leads to uncontrolled cell growth and tumor formation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 35 PN 369

choices.text: Multiple codons decode the same amino acid
Single codon decode for two amino acid
First nucleotide in codon responsible for degeneracy of codon
For a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated

questions.text: Degeneracy of genetic code means:
questions.solution:
Option A: Degeneracy in the genetic code is when multiple codons decode the same amino acid.

Some amino acids are encoded by several codons; for example, six different codons, UCU, UCC, UCA, UCG, AGU, and AGC all specify serine. Other amino acids, such as methionine and tryptophan, have a single codon.

Option B: For any specific codon, only a single amino acid is specified. Single codon never decodes for two amino acids during protein synthesis.

Option C: In general, the third nucleotide in a codon is less important than the first two in determining the specific amino acid to be incorporated, and this accounts for most of the degeneracy of the code.

Option D: For any specific codon, only a single amino acid is specified; with rare exceptions, the genetic code is unambiguous-that is, given a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated. However, it does not explain degeneracy.

The genetic code is virtually universal. An exception occurs in mitochondria, in which a few codons have meanings different than those shown in table.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 37 PN 394

questions.text: Operon, the unit of genetic expression consists of:
questions.solution:
Jacob and Monod in 1961 described their operon model in a classic paper. Their hypothesis was to a large extent based on observations on the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium E. coli. The molecular mechanisms responsible for the regulation of the genes involved in the metabolism of lactose are now among the best-understood in any organism.

β-Galactosidase hydrolyzes the β-galactoside lactose to galactose and glucose. The gene encoding β-galactosidase (lacZ) is clustered with the genes encoding lactose permease (lacY) and thiogalactoside transacetylase (lacA).

The genes encoding these three enzymes, along with the lac promoter and lac operator (a regulatory region), and the lacI gene encoding the LacI repressor are physically linked and constitute the lac operon.

So the operon model consists of related genes (Option A) along with operator (Option B) and promoter (Option C) sequences.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 38 PN 411

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with acute onset pain on his left great toe. X ray of the left foot shows punched out lesions with overhanging margins on the 1st metatarsal head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• G sign/Martel sign: Punched out lesion of bone with overhanging bony edges.
  • GOUT-
  • It is a disorder of purine metabolism characterized by hyperuricemia (uric acid >7 mg/dL) that leads to deposition of monosodium urate crystalsin joints and periarticular tissues and thereby precipitates recurrent attacks of acute synovitis and eventually leads to arthritis
  • The hyperuricemia in gout may be due to:
    • Underexcretion of uric acid (90%)
    • Overproduction of uric acid (10%)
  • Factors predisposing to gout:
    • Obese, alcoholic middle-aged (usually over 30 years) male patient
    • Dietary excess of purine-rich foods: Meat, beans, peas, cauliflower, lentils, spinach, mushrooms, alcohol.
    • Trauma, post-surgery
  • Pathogenesis of gout is the high body total urate levels that cause deposition of monosodium urate crystals (called as tophi) into the synovium of joints
  • Acute gout: It is characterized by sudden onset, severe joint pain with red, hot, swollen, shiny overlying skin that mimics septic arthritis. The most common site of involvement is the MTP joint of the great toe (podagra)
  • Chronic gout: Recurrent acute attacks in due course lead to chronic gout. It is asymmetric and polyarticular. Joints become eroded, painful and eventually stiff and deformed.
  • X-ray changes include:
    • Soft tissue swelling (may be the only sign during acute attack)
    • Periarticular deep erosions - Rat/Flea bitten appearance
    • Joint space narrowing
    • G sign/Martel sign- Punched out lesion of bone with overhanging bony edges.

Reference: Mohindra and Jain 1stedition page no 354

questions.text: A 25 year old man presents with gunshot injury to his right thigh. There is an entry wound of 1cm and no exit wound. He has also sustained comminuted fracture of distal femur and Popliteal A injury. What is the grade according to the Anderson Gustillo classification?
questions.solution:
If there is arterial injury that needs to be repaired, regardless of the amount of other soft tissue damage, it is considered as grade IIIC.

questions.text: Which of the following is feature of osteoarthritis of knee joint?
questions.solution:
• Radiological features of osteoarthritis
    • Joint space reduction (due to loss of cartilage)
    • Osteophytes formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis (due to condensation of trabeculae)
    • Subchondral cyst formation (due to osteonecrosis and seeping of synovial fluid into cracks)

Reference: Maheshwari Essential Orthopedics 5th edition page no 295

questions.text: An army recruit with smoking addiction has pain in his right foot for the last 3 months after he started training. He has point tenderness and pain in the forefoot which is aggravated by activity. What would be the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Stress fracture occurs due to abnormal loading of a normal bone. This is classically seen in individuals who perform repetitive, strenuous activities that he/she is not accustomed to.
  • The most common site of stress fracture is Tibia followed by 2nd metatarsal (March Fracture)

Reference: Rockwood and green adult fracture 8th edition, page-652

questions.text: 30 years old male comes to your clinic complaining of red and itchy eyes for the last 12 hrs. When asked for the past history, he recalls going to the emergency department 2 months ago for diarrhea. Patient also had diffuse joint pains and pain on urination for one month. He has tested negative for RA factor but is HLA B27 positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Conjunctivitis with history of urethritis and diarrhea is suggestive of Reactive arthritis. Most patients are in between 20 to 30 yrs with HLA B27 positive.
  • Reactive arthritis is thought to be caused by auto immune reaction to genitourinary or gastrointestinal infection.
  • Two forms are recognized: a dysenteric form and a sexually transmitted form. The former occurs with infection after the Shigella, Salmonella and Campylobacter species while the latter is seen in cases of urogenital tract infections with Chlamydia trachomatis, Mycoplasma genalium or Lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Reiter’s syndrome is a clinical triad of nonerosive reactive arthritis, urethritis and conjunctivitis
  • The usual age of onset is 20-40 years with men being affected more commonly than women (10:1).
  • X-rays usually show features of nonerosive arthritis of affected joints.
  • Most patients can be managed with symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs
  • Option A- Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic progressive inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy, presents with back pain and stiffness associated with uveitis and aortic regurgitation.it is strongly associated with HLA B27allele.
  • Option B- Lyme arthritis usually caused by bite from tick harboring spirochete borrelia burdgdorferi, presents with local skin rash, arthritis n arthralgia.
  • Option D- Psoriatic arthritis patient presents with skin and nail lesions along with arthritis.

Reference: Fundamentals of Orthopedics Mohindra and Jain page no 351.

questions.text: Three point bony relationship has diagnostic value in:
questions.solution:
• Three point bony relation is made with medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle and olecranon process
  • These 3 points will form an isosceles triangle which is congruent with the opposite side when the elbow is in flexion and comes to lie in a horizontal line when the elbow is extended.
  • Three point bony relationship will be disrupted in fractures of olecranon, medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar region and elbow dislocation.
  • In supracondylar fracture, however, three point bony relation is maintained

Reference: Maheshwari Orthopedics, 6thedition, page no 107

questions.text: 3 year old child was lifted up and spun around by his father holding his hand. Suddenly child started crying and was not allowing to touch his elbow. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pulled elbow, also known as nurse maid's elbow is a minor inferior subluxation of radial head that occurs when the upper limb is pulled by holding below the elbow. This commonly occurs in children below 5 years of age. Clinically the child will be in pain and will hold the forearm in pronation. X rays will usually be normal.
  • A dramatic cure is achieved by forcefully supinating and then flexing the elbow; the annular ligament slips back with a snap and the radial head relocates. A click may be felt in child's elbow while reducing it. Once this is done, the child stops crying and starts using his limb within minutes after reduction.

Reference: Maheshwari Essentials Ortho 5th edition, page no-105

questions.text: 40 years old female presents with history of fatigue, weight loss and poly-arthralgia for the last 5 years. Her hand and wrist radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• X ray shows 1. Severe osteopenia and 2. swan neck deformities in several fingers. Both these findings along with clinical history points towards RA.
  • Osteoarthritis- Heberden nodes and Bouchard nodes are seen.
  • Psoriatic arthritis- Pencil in cup deformity
  • Gout - Martel G sign and rat bitten appearance is seen.

Reference: Manish Kumar Varshney 1st edition page no 405

choices.text: Closed fracture of upper tibia with compartment syndrome and blisters over skin
Closed fracture shaft humerus with Radial nerve palsy
Fracture with burns wound over fracture site

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of external fixator?
questions.solution:
• Indications of external fixator
    1. Open fracture (grade 3b-3c- absolute indication, grade-2-3a-relative indication)
    2. Vascular injury
    3. Severe soft tissue injury
    4. Damage control orthopedics
  • Nerve injury is not an indication of external fixation

Reference: AO manual of principle of fracture management

questions.text: A 35 year old female was admitted to a hospital with fracture shaft of femur. After 2 days, she developed breathlessness and altered sensorium. Despite aggressive resuscitation efforts, she passed away three hours later in the intensive care unit. The autopsy finding in the lung tissue is shown below. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
• Image shows fat globules in lung tissues which is suggestive of fat embolism.
  • The fat globules may originate from bone marrow or adipose tissue. Fat embolism is more common following severe injuries with multiple fractures and fractures of major bones like femur, pelvis and tibia.
  • Symptom Triad of fat embolism: (i) cerebral; (ii) pulmonary and (iii) petechial rashes
  • In the cerebral type, the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma.
  • In the pulmonary type, tachypnea and tachycardia are the more prominent features.
  • The other common feature of fat embolism is a petechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Other options:

  • Crush syndrome - This syndrome results from massive crushing of the muscles, commonly associated with crush injuries sustained during earthquakes, air raids, mining and other such accidents.
  • Causes: Crushing of muscles results in entry of myohaemoglobin into the circulation, which precipitates in renal tubules, leading to acute renal tubular necrosis.
  • Consequences: Acute tubular necrosis produces signs of deficient renal functions such as scanty urine, apathy, restlessness and delirium. It may take 2-3 days for these features to appear.
  • Cardiogenic shock and pneumonia don't show this type of histology on biopsy images.

Reference: Maheshwari 5th edition, chapter 7, page no 44

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an IL-1 antagonist typically used as a second line agent in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• IL-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1R) is a naturally occurring molecule that blocks the biologic effects of the pro-inflammatory cytokine
  • IL-1. A recombinant form of human IL-1R, Anakinra, is used to manage rheumatoid arthritis patients who are refractory to more conventional forms of treatment.
  • Methotrexate and leflunomide are DMARD's, and are typically prescribed if low dose corticosteroids are ineffective. Adalimumab and etanercept are both TNF-alpha blockers.

Reference: Manish Kumar Varshney 1st edition page no 409

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy fell on an outstretched right arm. Which type of fracture is shown on this x-ray?
questions.solution:
• This is a fracture of the upper-third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. It may also result from a direct blow on the back of the upper forearm.
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation consist of fracture of the distal part of the radius with dislocation of distal radioulnar joint and an intact ulna.
  • Bowing fracture: the bone is bowed, but there is no discernible fracture. It is also called plastic deformation of bone.
  • Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures of long bones and are usually seen in young children, more commonly less than 10 years of age. They are commonly mid-diaphyseal, affecting the forearm and lower leg.

Reference: Apleys Orthopedics 9th edition, page no. 770

choices.text: Mature fibroblasts are seen at periphery and proliferating fibroblasts at the center
Cytological atypia and mitotic figures are seen at periphery and mature fibroblast at the center
Matures fibroblasts are seen at the center and proliferating fibroblasts at the periphery
Mature fibroblast along with cytological atypia and mitotic figures are seen at periphery

questions.text: TRUE about myositis ossificans
questions.solution:
MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS

Zonal phenomenon is a characteristic feature of Myositis ossificans. In the center actively proliferating fibroblast with numerous mitotic figures, cytological atypia and loose random arrangement is found. In the periphery more organized arrangement of mature fibroblast with transformation into mature osteoid is seen. This is in contrast to neoplastic lesion in which more mature cells are seen at the center

More about Myositis Ossificans (Aka Hematoma Ossificans)

It is a benign pathological bone formation (heterotopic ossification) in muscles and other soft tissues Trauma is the most common inciting event, but may occur without trauma in paraplegics, Guillain-Barre (GB) syndrome, acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) encephalopathy, closed head injury, following extensive burns and in a comatose patient. One-third cases are idiopathic.

Most commonly affected muscles are quadriceps, glutei and brachialis. However, the elbow joint is most commonly involved joint by myositis ossificans. After injury, massage to the elbow and vigorous passive physiotherapy may provoke the development of myositis ossificans.

Pathology: It is a calcium hydroxyapatite deposition in soft tissues being composed of a benign matrix rich in fibroblasts and osteoclast like giant cells.

Clinical features: Clinical features are divided into three phases:

Acute phase: After a few days to a few weeks of injury, patient develops pain swelling and stiffness of nearby joints.

Pseudotumoral phase: This comes after 2-3 weeks and characterized by painless hard mass.

Resolving phase: This comes after 3-6 months. Gradual resolution of the lesion may occur in this phase.

Radiology: Initial X-rays are normal. Calcification and mineralization are seen 2-3 weeks after the onset of symptoms and matures in next 3-6 months. Periosteal reaction is seen as laminations. There are three variants of the myositic mass. In stalked variant a peduncle is attached to the underlying bone. In sessile variant, the mass has a broad-based attachment to underlying periosteum. In a third variant bony mass is only attached to involved muscle.

Diagnosis: It can be made on clinical background in association with X-ray features. In doubtful cases diagnosis can be confirmed by biopsy. Biopsy also differentiates it from a bone-forming tumor like osteosarcoma due to the presence of zonal phenomena.

Treatment: In acute cases, treatment consists of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), ice, compression dressing, splintage for the involved limb and active range of motion physiotherapy. Passive stretching should be avoided, rather active exercises are to be encouraged. If required, excision of the ossified mass can be done after maturation, which usually takes a year or so (indicated by decreased levels of alkaline phosphatase and mature bone deposition on X-ray).

Reference: Maheshwari Ortho 5th edition, page number 52

choices.text: Retinal changes of fat or petechiae

questions.text: What is the major criteria for fat embolism?
questions.solution:
The three major factors for diagnosing fat embolism according to GURD’s criteria are

  1. Respiratory symptoms
  2. Cerebral symptoms and
  3. Petechial rashes.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page number 43

questions.text: Volkmann's ischemic contracture mostly involves which of the following mucles ?
questions.solution:
VOLKMANN ISCHEMIC CONTRACTURE-

  • It is a consequence of ischemic necrosis of muscles and nerves of forearm which are then replaced by fibrous tissue. Any obstruction to brachial artery caused by tight plaster, improper use of tourniquet, or compartment syndrome can lead to Volkmann ischemic contracture (VIC).

  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is the most common fracture associated with vascular injury (Brachial artery) and is the most common cause of compartment syndrome and Volkmann's ischemia in children.
  • Volkmann ischemic contracture most commonly involves FDP and median nerve.
  • A turn buckle splint is most commonly used for mild deformities.
  • In moderate cases the surgery of choice is the Maxpage's muscle sliding operation (erasing the common flexor origin and translating it distally on to the interosseous membrane). Severe cases require neurolysis, excision of the infarcted muscle mass and bone shortening procedures.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page number 102

questions.text: Putti platt's operation for shoulder instability involves overlapping and tightening of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Putti-platt operation (double breasting of subscapularis tendon) is one of the methods used for treating recurrent dislocation of shoulder. Double breasting of subscapularis tendon shortens it and limits external rotation of humerus thereby preventing the shoulder for going into abduction, external rotation position, which is the position in which most recurrent dislocation occurs. However, this procedure is only of historical importance and is no longer preferred as it limits significant movement.

Other commonly performed surgeries for recurrent dislocation are Bankart repair (arthroscopic/ open) and Bristow- Latarjet procedure

In Bristow- Latarjet procedure, the coracoid process along with the attached muscles (conjoint tendon) is osteotomized at its base and transferred down to be fixed to the anteroinferior margin of the glenoid to prevent the head from subluxating anteriorly.

Reference: Fundamentals of Orthopedics Mahindra 1stedition, page no 91

choices.text: Widening and haziness around SI joints
Narrowing and sclerosis around the SI joints

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest radiological sign in Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS)?
questions.solution:
• X-RAY FINDINGS IN ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS
  • Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis is the hallmark of AS.
  • X-ray signs develop first on the iliac side of SI joint. Haziness and widening of SI joint due to subchondral erosions are the earliest X-ray signs. This is usually accompanied by variable osteoporosis around the SI joint.
  • As the disease progresses sclerosis, new bone formation and calcification of SI and sacrotuberous ligaments around SI joint occurs leading to ankylosis (fibrous then bony) of the SI joint as the end result.
  • Radiographs of the lumbosacral spine show loss of lumbar lordosis, diffuse osteoporosis, calcification of anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, squaring of the vertebral bodies and bridging osteophytes (k/a syndesmophytes).
  • Eventually, the spine in advanced stages gives the classical bamboo spine appearance
  • Dagger sign refers to a single central radio dense line in the anteroposterior (AP) radiographs of spine related to ossification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments

Reference: Maheshwari Ortho 5th ;edition page no 291

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with foot pain after landing on his foot improperly while playing basketball last night. His X-ray is shown here. What is the correct diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• JONES FRACTURE- A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone.
  • Aviator -# neck of talus
  • Lovers -#calcaneum
  • March-# 2nd metatarsal neck

Reference: Maheshwari Ortho 5thedition, page no. 166

questions.text: A patient with fracture of femur shaft develops petechiae, respiratory distress and decreased sPO2, 3 days after injury. What in the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Fat embolism is often caused by physical trauma such as fracture of long bone, soft tissue trauma and burns.
  • Clinical Features- Triad of respiratory distress, CNS symptoms and Petechial rash.
  • Other features include tachycardia, tachypnea, increased temperature, hypoxemia (decreased sPO2), hypercapnea, thrombocytopenia.
  • Pathognomonic sign: Petechial rash on the upper anterior portion of the body, including the chest, neck, upper arm, axilla, shoulder, oral mucosa and conjunctivae.
  • Crush injury is compression of extremities or other parts of the body that causes muscle swelling and/or neurological disturbances in the affected areas of the body, while crush syndrome is localized crush injury with systemic manifestations. It is Characterized by major shock and renal failure after a crushing injury to skeletal muscle.
  • Hypostatic pneumonia is usually seen in elderly and debilitating patients. It results from infection developing in the dependent portions of the lungs due to decreased ventilation of those areas, with resulting failure to drain bronchial secretions.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5thedition, page no. 43

questions.text: A 40-year-old male sustained a fracture in his right knee as shown in the figure. What would be the treatment of choice in this fracture?
questions.solution:
• The x-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of patella, which is treated using tension band wiring.
  • Patella fractures are managed based on the fracture pattern.
    • Undisplaced fractures - cylinder cast.
    • Displaced transverse fractures - tension band wiring.
    • Comminuted fractures - patellectomy.
  • Osteochondral fracture

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-147.

choices.text: Stress fracture of the distal fibula 3-8 cm above lateral malleolus
Avulsion fracture of medial femoral condyle at the origin of the medial collateral ligament
Lateral tibial plateau avulsion fracture with anterior cruciate ligament tear
Salter-Harris Type III fracture of distal tibia

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Tillaux fracture?
questions.solution:
Tillaux-Chaput fracture: Avulsion of the anterior inferior tibio-fibular ligament from the anterior tibial margin (tibial counter-part of the Le-fort fracture). This is a Salter Harris type III injury. This is seen in adolescents and rare in adults.

Reference: Fundamentals of Orthopedics Mohindra and Jain page no 141, 1st edition.

questions.text: 60 years old man with diabetes mellitus presents with painless swollen right ankle joint. Radiograph of ankle joint shows destroyed joint with large number of loose bodies. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Charcot joint, also known as a neuropathic joint or Charcot (neuro/osteo) arthropathy, refers to a progressive degenerative/destructive joint disorder in patients with reduced / absent pain sensation and proprioception.
  • The most common cause is diabetes.
  • Most patients present with a limp, difficulty putting on shoes, or soft tissue swelling. But the clinching point is the absence of pain even in the presence of severe deformity and disability.
  • The characteristic physical findings are anesthetic or hypoesthetic feet (100% of patients), bony deformities (69% of patients), and soft tissue swelling (17% of patients). Many patients also have ulceration and abnormal callus formation.
  • The most common bony deformities are abnormal projections on the plantar arch (rocker sole) or other unusual prominence of the dorsal or medial arches of the midfoot or the MTP joint.
  • Treatment is difficult. Bracing is usually advised for some joints. CROW (charcot resistant orthotic walker) is now used for charcot’s joint of foot and ankle.

Reference: Maheshwari Ortho 5thedition, page no 294

questions.text: Which of the following components of the clubfoot deformity should be addressed first when using the Ponsetti method?
questions.solution:
PONSETI METHOD-

  • Ponsetti method of choice now with a success rate of >95%. This procedure consists of manipulating the foot for 1-3 minutes into corrected position, followed by holding the correction in an above knee cast (applied with knees flexed to 90°).
  • After 7 days, cast is removed, foot re-manipulated, and recasted for another week in successively more corrected position. Usually, 5 to 7 casts are sufficient and deformity gets corrected.
  • The order of correction is very important. It can be remembered by the pneumonic 'CAVE'. Cavus is corrected in the 1st cast by supinating the forefoot and dorsiflexing the 1st metatarsal.
  • Forefoot must never be pronated as it will increase the cavus deformity.
  • Adduction and varus are then corrected simultaneously in the subsequent casts by abducting the forefoot in supination with counter pressure being applied at talar head.
  • Lastly, equinus is corrected, by dorsiflexing the fully abducted foot.
  • In case dorsiflexion is difficult beyond neutral then a percutaneous tenotomy of Tendo Achilles is done to achieve adequate dorsiflexion.

Reference: MAHESHWARI ORTHO 5TH EDITION PAGE NO 214.

questions.text: Vascular sign of Narath is not seen in
questions.solution:
• Vascular sign of Narath: inability to feel femoral pulse against femoral head in the inguinal region.
    • It is positive in all conditions where the femoral head is not present in its normal position. Eg. Traumatic hip dislocation, DDH, Tom Smith arthritis and Girdlestone arthroplasty
  • Useful signs in orthopedics
    • VIC: Volkmann’s sign
    • Piano key sign: Distal radio ulnar joint instability (e.g., Madelung deformity, Malunited colles fracture etc.)
    • De Quervain’s syonvitis: Finkelstein test
    • Flexor tenosynovitis: Kanavel’s signs
    • AVN hip: Sectoral sign
    • Iliopsoas tendonitis: Ludloff sign

Reference: Fundamentals of Orthopedics Mohindra and Jain 1st edition, page no 100

Open reduction with cannulated screw fixation

questions.text: A 65-year-old female sustained the injury seen in Figure after a slip and fall. She is an avid golfer and walks the course on most days. Her past medical history includes borderline hypertension and migraine headaches. Which treatment option has shown to have the lowest re-operation rate and best clinical outcomes scores in this patient population?
questions.solution:
• Figure shows a displaced right femoral neck fracture in an active, healthy elderly patient.
  • Treatment of her hip fracture with total hip arthroplasty (THA) has shown to have the lowest re-operation rates and best functional outcome scores when compared to internal fixation devices and hemiarthroplasty.
  • Large studies have shown the incidence of femoral head AVN to be approximately 30-45% with displaced femoral neck fractures (Garden III-IV). For this reason, treatment of these injuries in elderly patients have supported arthroplasty over ORIF.
  • Treatment of patients with THA vs. hemiarthroplasty have also been investigated. Studies have shown that THA has lower re-operation rates and improved functional outcome scores in younger, active elderly patients compared to hemiarthroplasty.
  • Answers A, B: Arthroplasty of any type has been shown to have the least number of complications and greatest functional outcome scores compared to internal fixation devices. Indications for treatment of femoral neck fractures with internal fixation include: (1) stable or unstable fractures in young or physiologically young patients (2) stable fragility fractures (Garden I and II) in low demand elderly patients.
  • Answer C: Hemiarthroplasty is most appropriate for displaced femoral neck fractures (Garden III or IV) in low-functional demand elderly patients.

Reference: Maheshwari Essential Ortho 5th edition, page no 133

choices.text: It usually presents with painful limp
It may present with pain in the knee
It is associated with intermittent pyrexia in the early stages
It frequently presents with limitation of all hip movements, especially internal rotation and abduction.

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is not true about Perthes disease?
questions.solution:
• In contrast to septic arthritis Perthes disease patients do not have fever which is important differential diagnosis.
  • PERTHES DISEASE-The disease occurs commonly in boys in the age group of 5-10 years.
  • The child presents with pain in the hip, often radiating to the knee. There may be limping or hip stiffness.
  • On examination, findings may be minimal - sometimes the only findings being a limitation of abduction and internal rotation and shortening.

Reference: Maheshwari Essentials Ortho 5th edition page no. 318

questions.text: 70 years old male, known case of chronic renal failure suffers from a pathological fracture of his right femur. What could be the underlying mechanism that has caused this?
questions.solution:
• In chronic renal failure, 3 things happen-
    1. The 1-alpha hydroxylation and activation of vitamin D fails,
    2. Persistent loss of calcium through urine and
    3. Phosphate retention.
  • When this happens, insoluble calcium phosphate forms in the body and removes calcium from the circulation. Both processes lead to hypocalcaemia.
  • Whenever there is hypocalcemia, the parathyroid gland senses it and releases PTH. This elevation of PTH in response to hypocalcemia is called secondary hyperparathyroidism. The elevated level of PTH will cause demineralization of bone, causing the ones to weaken and undergo pathological fractures. The bone damage occurring in renal failure is called renal osteodystrophy.
  • Please note that secondary hyperparathyroidism is also seen in rickets and osteomalacia and for that matter, any condition causing hypocalcemia.
  • Renal osteodystrophy.
    1. Bone and joint pain are common, as are limb deformities.
    2. Pathological fractures are common.
    3. Diagnosis- the clinching biochemical change is elevated phosphate levels. The PTH is also elevated due to decreased levels of calcium or 1, 25-dihydroxy-vitamin D3 and there will be altered renal function tests.
    4. In people with chronic renal failure, treatment consists of dietary restriction of phosphorus, supplements with an active form of vitamin D such as calcitriol, doxercalciferol, paricalcitol, etc., and phosphate binders which can be divided into calcium-based and non-calcium based.
  • But caused more issues with low blood calcium levels and vomiting.
    1. Most people with hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic kidney disease will improve after renal transplantation, but many will continue to have a degree of residual hyper parathyroidism(tertiary hyperparathyroidism) posttransplant with associated risk of bone loss, etc.,

Reference: Dabbagh S. Renal osteodystrophy, Curr Opin Pediatr, 1998 Apr. 10(2): 190-6.

questions.text: Bone within Bone appearance is seen in?
questions.solution:
X-ray features of osteopetrosis:

  1. Generalized osteosclerosis of bones.
  2. Loss of cortico medullary differentiation
  3. Grossly narrowed/absent medullary canal
  4. Cube-like bones(carpals and tarsals)
  5. Erlenmeyer flask deformity of distal femur
  6. Sandwich vertebra
  7. Endobone formation(bone within bone appearance)

Reference: Postgraduate Orthopedics by Manish Kumar Varshney, 1st Edition, Page Number-96.

questions.text: Which of the following soluble protein involved in electron transport chain act as electron carrier?
questions.solution:
C) Cytochrome cis the soluble protein involved in the electron transport chain (ETC) that acts as an electron carrier.

  • Cytochrome c is a heme-containing protein that plays a crucial role in the electron transport chain (ETC) located in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • It serves as an electron carrier and shuttles electrons between Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) and Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the ETC.
  • Coenzyme Q (Option A) is also involved in the ETC but is not a soluble protein. It is a lipid-soluble molecule.
  • Cytochrome oxidase (Option B) is a component of Complex IV in the ETC but is not a soluble protein.
  • Complex II (Option D) is part of the ETC but is not a soluble protein acting as an electron carrier like cytochrome c.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 13 PN 119

questions.text: Membranes are asymmetric structure. Which of the following component present in higher in inner leaflet of membrane?
questions.solution:
Option A: Phosphatidyl choline also known as lecithin, preen in outer leaflet of membrane.

Option B: Phosphatidyl ethanolamine also known as cephalin & Phosphatidyl serine are present in inner leaflet of membrane.

Option C: Sphingomyelin also known as Phosphatidyl sphingol is present in outer leaflet of membrane.

Option D: Carbohydrates usually attached with protein and lipids, present on outer side of membrane

  • Different composition of lipid and protein in inner and outer layer of membrane
  • Asymmetry in proteins: C terminal end of protein is at cytosolic side, N terminal at outer side
  • Asymmetry in Lipid: Phosphatidyl ethanolamine, Phosphatidyl serine in inner side and Phosphatidyl choline, Sphingomyelin in outer side
  • Asymmetry in Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates usually attached with protein and lipids, present on outer side of membrane

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 40 PN 464

choices.text: It is an invagination in the plasma membrane.
A protein caveolin play an important role in formation of caveolae
Each caveolin monomer is anchored to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane
Caveolae may derive from lipid rafts.

questions.text: All of the following are features of caveola, except:
questions.solution:
Option A: A caveola is a specialized structure of plasma membrane. It is an invagination in the plasma membrane.

Option B: The protein caveolin appears to play an important role in the formation of caveolae and occurs as a dimer.

Option C: Each caveolin monomer is anchored to the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane by three palmitoyl molecules.

Option D: Caveolae may derive from lipid rafts.

  • Caveolae are observable by electron microscopy as flask, or tube-shaped indentations of the cell membrane into the cytosol.
  • Proteins detected in caveolae include various components of the signal transduction system (eg, the insulin receptor and some G proteins), the folate receptor, and endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS).
  • Caveolae and lipid rafts are active areas of research, and ideas concerning them and their roles in various biologic processes are rapidly evolving.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 40 PN 466

questions.text: Which of the following hormone inhibit Adenyl cyclase and reduce production of cAMP?
questions.solution:
Option A: Somatostatin can inhibit adenyl cyclase enzyme and reduce production of cAMP.

Calcitonin (Option B), Glucagon (Option C) & ADH (Option D) can activate adenyl cyclase enzyme and increase production of cAMP.

cAMP (cyclic AMP), a nucleotide derived from ATP through the action of adenylyl cyclase; Different peptide hormones can either stimulate (s) or inhibit (i) the production of cAMP from adenylyl cyclase through the action of the G-proteins.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 42 PN 503

questions.text: Which of the following hormone receptor has intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity?
questions.solution:
Option A: The insulin, EGF, and IGF-1 receptors have intrinsic protein tyrosine kinase activities located in their cytoplasmic domains.

Option B: Glucagon act via cell surface receptor, but does not have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.

Option C & Option D: Steroid hormone & Thyroid hormone act via intracellular receptor, such receptor does not have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 42 PN 508

questions.text: Proteins are linear polymers of amino acids. They fold into compact structures. Sometimes, these folded structures associate to form homo-or- heterodimers. Which one of the following refers to this associated form?
questions.solution:
Primary Structure is the linear sequence of amino acids held together by peptide bonds in its peptide chains. Bond involved in primary structure is Peptide Bond, a type of covalent bond.

Secondary Structure

  • Configurational relationship between residues which are about 3-4 amino Acids apart in linear sequence.
  • The folding of short (3- to 30- residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units
  • Bonds involved in the secondary structure are primarily noncovalent bonds like:
    • Hydrogen Bond (Most important Bond)
    • Hydrophobic Bond
    • Electrostatic Bond (Ionic Bond, Salt Bridges)
    • van der Waals forces.

Tertiary structure: The entire three-dimensional confor- mation of a polypeptide is referred to as tertiary structure. Quaternary structure: If more than one polypeptide aggregate to form one functional protein, the spatial relationship between the polypeptide subunits is referred to as quaternary structure.

Bonds involved in Tertiary and Quaternary Structures are primarily noncovalent bonds.

  • Hydrophobic Interaction
  • Hydrogen Bond
  • Electrostatic Bond
  • Van der Waal's Forces

Some covalent bonds may be present, like disulphide bonds (both intra- & inter-strand) and cross links between side chains of strands

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 39

questions.text: An alpha helix of a protein is most likely to be disrupted if a missense mutation introduces the following amino acid within the alpha helical structure:
questions.solution:

  • But proline is present in the first turn of the alpha helix. Separatory Techniques of Proteins, Study of Protein Structure, Precipitation of Proteins

questions.text: In Michaelis Menten reaction, if substrate concentration is equal to Km then
questions.solution:
The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates in mathematical terms the relationship between initial reaction velocity vi and substrate concentration.

The Michaelis constant Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) attainable at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

Km thus has the dimensions of substrate concentration.

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 79

choices.text: Troponin levels rise for 2 to 6 hours after an MI and remain elevated for 4 to 10 days
Troponin is a complex of three proteins involved in muscle contraction in smooth and cardiac muscle.
In addition to MI, other heart muscle damage also elevates serum troponin levels.
Immunological measurement of plasma levels of cardiac troponins I and T provide sensitiveand specific indicators of damage to heart muscle

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Troponins Except
questions.solution:
A) Troponin levels rise for 2 to 6 hours after an MI and remain elevated for 4 to 10 days: This statement is true. Troponin levels rise after a heart attack (MI) and remain elevated for several days.

C) In addition to MI, other heart muscle damage also elevates serum troponin levels: This statement is true. Troponin elevation is not exclusive to MI and can occur in response to other forms of heart muscle damage.

D) Immunological measurement of plasma levels of cardiac troponins I and T provides sensitive and specific indicators of damage to heart muscle: This statement is true. Troponin I and T are sensitive and specific markers of heart muscle damage, and their measurement is a standard diagnostic method for detecting MI.

The incorrect statement is B) Troponin is a complex of three proteins involved in muscle contraction in smooth and cardiac muscle. Troponin is indeed a complex of three proteins (Troponin C, Troponin I, and Troponin T), but it is primarily involved in muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle, not in smooth muscle.

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 69

questions.text: Which of the following is the major end product of nitrogen metabolism in humans?
questions.solution:
Urea is the major end product of nitrogen catabolism in humans; humans are ureotelic.

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 292

questions.text: Which is elevated in pyridoxal phosphate deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Urinary metabolite in Vitamin B6 deficiency: Xanthurenic acid
  • Urinary Metabolite in Folic Acid Deficiency: Formimino Glutamic acid, Homocystine
  • Urinary metabolite in Vitamin B12 deficiency: Homocystine, Methyl Malonic Acid
  • 5-HIAA is elevated in carcinoid syndrome

Tryptophan metabolism -

  • Tryptophan is degraded to amphibolic intermediates via the kynurenine-anthranilate pathway.
  • Tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase opens the indole ring, incorporates molecular oxygen, and forms N-formylkynurenine.
  • Hydrolytic removal of the formyl group of N-formylkynurenine, catalyzed by kynurenine formylase, produces kynurenine.
  • Since kynureninase requires pyridoxal phosphate, excretion of xanthurenate in response to a tryptophan load is diagnostic of vitamin B6 deficiency.

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 306,308

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray spine shows calcification of IV disk. On adding Benedict's reagent to urine, it gives greenish brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Alkaptonuria. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism.

Biochemical defect- Homogentisate Oxidase deficiency leads to accumulation of Homogentisic Acid (Homogentisate) which polymerises to form Alkaptone bodies.

Clinical presentation-

  • Normal Life till 3rd or 4th decade.
  • Urine darkens on exposure to air is the only manifestation in children.
  • In adults Ochronosis: Alkaptone bodies in intervertebral disk, cartilage of nose, pinna etc.
  • No mental retardation

Laboratory Diagnosis-

  • Alkalization increase darkening of urine.
  • Benedicts test positive in urine because homogentisic acid is reducing agent.
  • Ferric Chloride test positive.
  • Silver Nitrate Test positive.

Treatment- Symptomatic treatment


Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 304

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic defect is seen in Type I Tyrosinemia?

questions.text: Mousy body odor in PKU is due to:
questions.solution:
Clinical Manifestations of phenylketonuria (PKU) -

  • The affected infant is normal at Profound mental retardation develops gradually if the infant remains untreated. Cognitive delay may not be evident for the 1st few months.
  • Some may have a seborrheic or eczematoid rash, which is usually mild and disappears as the child grows older.
  • These children have an unpleasant odor of phenylaceticacid, which has been described as musty or mousey.

Reference: Vasudevan and Sreekumari 8/e p292

questions.text: Which of the following would not act as source of glycine by transamination?
questions.solution:
Glycine aminotransferases can catalyze the synthesis of glycine from glyoxylate and glutamate or alanine.

Additional routes for glycine formation are from choline and from serine (by Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase).
