questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is diagnosed with bipolar disorder, manic type, when she was hospitalized after becoming psychotic, hypersexual, severely agitated and unable to sleep. She is started on a medication in the acute phase of her illness. Which of the following medications, recommended for acute use in manic patients, is recommended to be continued on into maintenance therapy?
questions.solution:
• Lithium, carbamazepine and valproic acid are the agents most often used in the long-term maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder.
  • Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines, while very helpful in the acute treatment of bipolar mania, should be discontinued as soon as the patient is in a stable state and not used in long-term maintenance unless absolutely necessary, given the risk of movement disorders and dependence, respectively.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 29th, Psychopharmacological treatment, Page no: 985.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought into the emergency department after he is picked up by police for wandering around his neighborhood naked. On examination, the patient states that he is 'receiving amazing messages from the cosmosphere' and that he believes that he is destined to do something 'catastrophically wonderful' for the world. He is alternately euphoric and then irritable with the examiner. He states that he wants to go home in the new car he just charged on his American Express card. He denies medical illnesses. The urine drug screen is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this man?
questions.solution:
• The man is presenting with labile mood, inappropriate behavior, grandiose thoughts and excessive spending, all hallmarks of bipolar disorder.
  • Because he is clearly manic at the moment, a cyclothymic disorder, with its smaller highs than full blown mania, is unlikely.
  • Narcissistic personality disorder does not present with frank psychosis.
  • Schizophrenia would be unlikely to present with the labile mood and excessive spending.
  • Schizoaffective disorder would likely present with a background of psychosis with new affective symptoms superimposed.
  • Because we must assume there is no prior history beyond what we have been told in the scenario, bipolar disorder is the best fit.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 8th, Mood disorders, Page no. 371.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the psychiatric out-patient-clinic with increased rate, tone and volume of speech. On asking anything, he would reply with unnecessary and insignificant information with elaborate detailing. Such over-inclusion of extraneous information would make it difficult to follow his train of thought or arrive at a meaningful answer. Such a speech pattern can be present in all of the conditions, except:
questions.solution:
• The characteristic pattern of formal thought disorder described in this case is called circumstantiality
  • Circumstantiality occurs when thinking proceeds slowly with many unnecessary and trivial details, but finally the point is reached
  • The goal of thinking is never completely lost and thinking proceeds towards it by an intricate and convoluted path
  • It is seen typically in manic episodes of bipolar mood disorder and schizoaffective disorder, in personality traits associated with temporal lobe epilepsy (GestautGeschwind Syndrome), in obsessive personality traits
  • It is uncommon in Schizotypal personality disorder which is characterized by social withdrawnness, isolation and decreased social interaction

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, third edition, Chapter 4 Disorders of Thought and Speech, Page no. 45

questions.text: All of the following delusional themes are mood congruent in a patient of Major Depressive Disorder, except:
questions.solution:
• In depression, delusions of guilt, poverty, nihilism, reference are commonly seen to be mood-congruent
  • However, grandiose delusions in which a person believes himself to be of supreme importance is commonly seen as a feature of mania and not depression

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, third edition, Chapter 4 Disorders of Thought and Speech, Page no: 51

questions.text: A patient presented with sensations of small animals or insects crawling under his right lower limb. Such symptom can be indicative of all the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
• Sensations of small insects or animals crawling under body signify tactile hallucinations and is also known as formication
  • It is seen commonly in several conditions like:
    1. Cocaine intoxication, where such tactile hallucinations and persecutory delusions are together termed as cocaine bugs
    2. Delusional parasitosis, where person has a delusional belief of insects or animals invading his body and accordingly tactile hallucinations may be present as an extension of this delusion
    3. Delirium
    4. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders
    5. Organic brain pathology like cerebrovascular stroke, Parkinson's disease, Dementia
  • Generalized anxiety disorder falls under neurotic spectrum
  • It is not characterized by psychotic symptoms like hallucinations

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, third edition, Chapter 3 Disorders of Perception, Page no. 33

choices.text: It involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain
Repetitive TMS is a useful treatment in refractory cases of OCD
ECT is preferred over TMS in treatment resistant cases of depression

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Transcranial magnetic stimulation(TMS)?
questions.solution:
Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation(TMS):

  • TMS is an example of non-invasive stimulation of focal regions of the brain using magnetic fields.
  • It can be used for research or therapeutically without the need for anesthesia.
  • TMS involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain.
  • Repetitive TMS(rTMS) has a role in the treatment of resistant OCD(Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder).
  • ECT(Electroconvulsive Therapy) is considered the gold standard therapy in treatment-resistant depression and is preferred over TMS for certain cases.

False about Transcranial magnetic stimulation(TMS):

A) It is an invasive procedure

  • TMS is not an invasive procedure; it is a non-invasive neurostimulation technique that uses magnetic fields for brain stimulation.

The other options are true:

B) TMS involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain.

C) Repetitive TMS(rTMS) is a useful treatment in refractory cases of OCD. rTMS involves repeated sessions of stimulation.

D) ECT is preferred over TMS in treatment-resistant cases of depression, as ECT is often considered when other treatments, including TMS, have not been effective for severe depression.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 30.2th, Other Brain Stimulation methods, Page number: 1073.

questions.text: A patient on antipsychotics x 3 weeks, presented with high fever, body pain, raised CPK and myoglobinuria. Which medicine can be more beneficial for the patient?

Clinical signs are suggestive of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome.

questions.text: A patient believes that one real person is replaced by another, as shown in photo. What is the probable diagnosis?

Capgrass Syndrome: Patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter. It is also known as "DELUSION OF DOUBLE".

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidaemia is admitted to the medicine unit for intravenous antibiotics for treatment of pneumonia. After 2 days he becomes increasingly anxious, with complaints of 'shaking' and sweating. His vitals demonstrate a temperature of 100.4 F, blood pressure of 170/97 mm Hg, pulse of 110 beats per min and respirations of 16 breaths/min. On examination he appears diaphoretic and flushed, with a coarse tremor of his upper extremities bilaterally. Laboratory test results are significant for slightly elevated AST, ALT and GGT. Review of his chart reveals a long history of daily, heavy alcohol use. When confronted with this information, the patient reluctantly admits to drinking 'one fifth' of vodka plus several beers daily, with little sobriety. His last drink was the day prior to admission. Administration of which of the following medications would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient is most likely experiencing acute alcohol withdrawal which is characterized by signs of sympathetic nervous system stimulation such as:
    • Elevated vital signs
    • Diaphoresis
    • Flushing
    • Tremor
    • Insomnia and anxiety
  • It can occur anywhere between 1 and 4 days after cessation or significant reduction in alcohol intake
  • This patient's history, clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with a history of regular, heavy alcohol use.
  • Other complications of alcohol withdrawal include:
    • Withdrawal seizures(12-48 hours after the last drink)
    • Delirium tremens(24-96 hours after the last drink)
  • The mainstay of treatment for alcohol withdrawal is with:
    • Benzodiazepines - Lorazepam, Oxazepam Either tapering the dose over several days or (in mild-to-moderate withdrawal), with a symptom-triggered approach, utilizing the Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment(CIWA) scale.
  • Acamprosate and Naltrexone are not appropriate for treating alcohol withdrawal, rather they are used in some cases to reduce craving and promote abstinence.(OPTION D)
  • Disulfiram is also not used to manage alcohol withdrawal, instead it is used as a deterrent to prevent a patient from consuming alcohol.(OPTION B)
  • Thiamine, while often depleted in alcoholics and necessary in the treatment of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, also does not address the pathophysiology of alcohol withdrawal.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 20.2, Alcohol-related disorders, Page no. 638.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is admitted to a psychiatric unit for depression with suicidal ideation and detoxification. He has a long history of dependence upon both alcohol and cocaine. Which of the following signs is most characteristic of early alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
• Tremor is the most characteristic sign of alcohol withdrawal.
  • Vital signs are elevated in alcohol withdrawal because of autonomic hyperactivity(OPTION A)
  • Patients generally have insomnia as a result, not hypersomnia(OPTION B)
  • Hallucinations associated with alcohol withdrawal usually resolve within a week, while those occurring in delirium tremens usually resolve with the delirium.
  • Cocaine withdrawal more typically involves hypersomnia and hyperphagia.(OPTION B)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, edition Eleventh, Chapter 20.2, Alcohol-Related Disorders, Page no. 625.

questions.text: A 25 year old female is presented to OPD with complaints of agitation, muttering to herself and sleep disturbances. She claims that her husband has stolen the baby from her womb. She has delivered a healthy child three weeks back, however has not taking care of the baby. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Nihilistic delusion is associated postpartum and duration is around 3 weeks. Diagnosis is Postpartum psychosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Mellanby effect?
questions.solution:
• Mellanby effect suggests that intoxicating effects are greater when the blood alcohol concentration is rising than when it is falling.
  • For this reason, the rate of absorption bears directly on the intoxication response.

questions.text: This syndrome presents with affected individuals being cortically blind but unaware of it and hence deny they have a problem. Patients start falling over furniture as they can't see. However, they believe they can still see and describe their environments in detail but are wrong in their description. Identify this syndrome.
questions.solution:
Anton's syndrome (Anton-Babinski syndrome):

  • Occurs following damage to the occipital lobe.
  • Affected individuals are cortically blind but are unaware of this and deny they have a problem (Anosognosia). It often presents as the patient starts falling over furniture as they can't see. Affected individuals believe they can still see and describe their environments in detail but are wrong in their description (confabulation).

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatric, Chapter 1.2 Functional Neuroanatomy, Page number 6.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a history of motor and vocal tics with Obsessive Compulsive symptoms that are worse in the winter and early spring months. Which of the following pathologies would be most important to rule out before starting treatment of Tourette Disorder?

  • Rapid treatment of streptococcal infections and prevention of reinfection may impact the clinical course of such children.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her daughter after she found her mother rummaging in the garbage cans outside her home. The daughter states that the patient has never had any behaviour like this previously. On interview, the patient states she sees "Martians hiding around her home and on occasion, hears them too. "She also demonstrates a constructional apraxia, with difficulty drawing a clock and intersecting pentagons. All of these symptoms point to a medical cause for this patient's behaviour except one. Which symptom is common in patients with a psychiatric cause for their behaviour(i.e., not a medical cause)?
questions.solution:
AUDITORY HALLUCINATIONS

  • Seen quite commonly in psychiatrically caused psychoses, but the rest of the items on the options list speak to the opposite, that is, a medical cause for the psychosis.
  • Other signs that point to a medical cause could be other mental status signs such as
    • Speech
    • Movement or gait disorders
    • Problems with alertness
    • Memory
    • Concentration
    • Orientation
    • Concurrent substance abuse history or medical problem

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 7.1, Schizophrenia, Page no. 313.

She has a very unstable relationship with her boyfriend and she is preoccupied with her weight and uncertain about her sexuality. What is the most likely diagnosis here?

This is a case of BPD: Frequent mood swings, Lability, Self destructive behaviour.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl reported having episodes where she felt as if she lives behind a glass or in a bubble and feels detached from thoughts, body and feeling. The figure below is apt as per her description. Such a condition is seen in all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
• The above case scenario depicts depersonalization de-realisation disorder.
  • It is common in seizure patients and migraine sufferers.
  • They can also occur with use of psychedelic drugs, especially marijuana, lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) and mescaline and less frequently as a side effect of some medications, such as anticholinergic agents. (Option A)
  • It has also been described after certain types of meditation, deep hypnosis, extended mirror or crystal gazing and sensory deprivation experiences; as well as panic disorder, major depressive disorder, acute stress disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder or another dissociative disorder. (Option B & C)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 12, Dissociative disorders, Page number 455.

questions.text: Klein-Levin syndrome is characterised by all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
• Kleine-Levin syndrome is a relatively rare condition consisting of recurrent periods of prolonged sleep (from which patients may be aroused) with intervening periods of normal sleep and alert waking.
  • During the hypersomniac episodes, wakeful periods are usually marked by withdrawal from social contacts and return to bed at the first opportunity.
  • It predominantly afflicts males in early adolescence; however, it can occur later in life and in females. With few exceptions, the first attack occurs between the ages of 10 and 21 years.
  • In its classic form, the recurrent episodes are associated with extreme sleepiness (18-hour to 20-hour sleep periods), voracious eating, hyper sexuality, and disinhibition (e.g., aggression)
  • Episodes → last for a few days up to several weeks.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 16, Normal Sleep and Sleep-wake Disorders, Page no. 546.
